nodes.message: Option only available here if you've already talked to Thomas during this event.

nodes.text: Esme told me that the reason she did so bad on the test was that she has trouble reading the Master's writing.
She does? I can understand why she had trouble with the test then. That test was tough for me to answer and I could read it.
You know, I think she'd really like some help with this - no one likes to fail.

nodes.name: Helping Esme - I Hope.
nodes.description: I talked to Thomas and tried to get him to help Esme. Hope this works out. Thomas seems like a nice guy.

nodes.text: You are right, Shawn. I should really talk with her later about this. Maybe I can help her.
Good - I know she'll appreciate your help.
I'm sure I'll have another chance to talk to Thomas later.
I don't have anything else to say to Thomas.
I don't have anything else to say to Thomas.
I don't have anything else to say to Thomas.
I don't have anything else to say to Thomas.
I don't have anything else to say to Thomas.
I said everything I want to say to Thomas right now.
Hi there, Shawn here.
I'm Thomas Kent. Welcome to Hero University, Shawn.
Thanks. It hasn't been much of a welcome till now.
It's an interesting place, this old castle and university. It's full of surprises.
Good thing I like surprises, then.
What do you think about this "Disbarred Bards" class?
I really don't know what to think about it. I grew up with a strong sense of what is Good and what is Evil. Good people do good things.
With this class, it's sometimes hard to figure out what is right and what is wrong.
Why did you come to this school?
I had a scholarship to the University. Besides, I always wanted to be a hero.
What do you practice in this room?
I practice just about everything. It's all new to me.

options.text: Ask What Shawn Needs to Know About This School

nodes.text: Tell me, what do you think I need to know about this school to get along here?
I suggest that you check out the amazing library here at the school. It has books on almost every subject. It's a fine place to study and learn.
I'll keep that in mind if I ever feel a burning need to study.
Goodbye then.
Goodbye.
So how are things going for you today?
Fine, I guess. What about you - what do you think of the school so far?

options.text: Say Something Clever to Make Friends With Thomas

nodes.text: I feel like I need a compass and a map just to find the dining hall.
It's not that difficult to get around the castle, once you get used to it.

options.text: Say Something Snarky to Make Friends With Thomas

nodes.text: Between Terk, Urwald, and the fact that our class is in a torture chamber, I can't tell if this is a hero school or a reform school.
The Master may seem strict, but he is a good teacher. I've learned a lot since coming here.

options.text: Say Something Polite to Make Friends With Thomas

nodes.text: It's kind of fun exploring this castle.
Yes, it's like we're caught up in some medieval bard's tale of knights in armor, except that we don't bash one another with swords.
Yeah, but instead of medieval bards, we're the remedial bards.
How do you like being in the 'Disbarred Bards' class?
I really wanted to be a Paladin like my father, so I can't say I'm happy about being a bard. Particularly not a disbarred one.
Good luck with your practicing.
Thank you.
Don't let Katie discourage you, Thomas. I'm sure you'll get better.
He can hardly get worse.

options.text: Say Something Clever to Rebuke Katie

nodes.text: Seems like Thomas is the only one of us who doesn't have the makings of a scoundrel or a thief. Most people would think that's a good thing.

options.text: Say Something Snarky to Amuse Katie

nodes.text: That last throw was the best so far - it hit the target. Shame you were aiming at a different target.

options.text: Say Something Polite to Support Thomas

nodes.text: You have to give Thomas some credit, Katie. He may have a lousy throwing arm, but he's not giving up.
Maybe someday, he'll even manage to hit the target.
So why are you in this class instead of the Paladin Class? Did you fail the 'holier than thou' requirement?
Paladins aren't 'holier than thou.' if anything, Paladins tend to be too humble. And Lady Moira here is very kind and sweet.
If I work hard enough to impress Master von Urwald with my diligence, maybe he'll recommend that I transfer to the Paladin classes.
Your determination is inspiring. Or maybe that's tiring? Either way, I'll leave you to it.
Goodbye.
Looks like you're getting the hang of throwing daggers.
Thanks. I'm starting to get a feel for it now.

options.text: Say Something Clever to Encourage Thomas

nodes.text: Your life could depend on that skill one day.
Right now, if my life depends on throwing daggers, I'm doomed.

options.text: Say Something Snarky to Amuse Thomas

nodes.text: Maybe you just need some more incentive...
What if we pin a picture of Sosi on the bullseye?
You know, that just might help...
And it's not even against the rules!
What if we pin a picture of Terk on the bullseye?
That might work for you, but I have no wish to harm Mr. Terk.
Also, that would violate School Rule Number 35 - "Always Show proper Respect towards Faculty and Staff."
That's a rule? I guess that certain staff members like Mr. Terk have very thin skins.
Esme is really upset about her test score.
I feel for her. I hate to do poorly in anything.
Have you talked to her about it?
No. I didn't want to risk making things worse.
She told me that the reason she did so bad on the test was that she has trouble reading the Master's writing.
She does? I can understand why she had trouble with the test then. That test was tough for me to answer and I could read it.
You know, I think she'd really like some help with this - no one likes to fail.

nodes.name: Helping Esme - I Hope.
nodes.description: I talked to Thomas and tried to get him to help Esme. Hope this works out. Thomas seems like a nice guy.

nodes.text: You are right, Shawn. I should really talk with her later about this. Maybe I can help her.
Good - I know she'll appreciate your help.
I don't think it would make things worse...
If she wanted to speak to me, she would have. I must respect her privacy.
Sometimes, when we most need help - we can't ask... just saying.
So what do you think of Signore Sosi?
Caesari is intelligent, skilled, and generally polite to me, but I don't trust him. There's something about his manner that makes me watch my back.
That's because Sosi looks for easy targets.
See you later!
Thanks, Shawn. Farewell.
So you heard noises in the night, too? Maybe the thief is using the bathroom.
That's possible... the bath towels were missing this morning.
That was true also on our side.
Odd, I didn't notice the missing towels. Guess it's a good thing I didn't try to take a bath this morning.
It's not a good thing for the rest of us, Shawn. Baths are your friend.

options.text: Say Something Clever About the Thief

nodes.text: It's going to be difficult to catch the thief. It's not like we can just throw a dagger at him to stop him.
Particularly not if you are Thomas.

options.text: Say Something Snarky About the Thief and Thomas

nodes.text: At least we can tell the thief's not a Rogue student. He's far too noisy.
Unless you're the thief. If you sneak as well as you throw, then you'd probably wake us all up when you go down the hall.

options.text: Say Something to Cheer Everyone Up

nodes.text: I'm sure we'll be able to catch this thief. We can outsmart him and prove to the rest of the school that Rogues rule!
Great idea, except for the part where we're "disbarred Bards", not Rogues.
So what's your take on the school thief?
When Esme said the thief was a 'something' instead of a 'someone', I thought at first of a Drat, or a packrat dragging objects back to the nest.
But from the reports of what has been stolen, the thief must be capable of opening doors and taking things out of drawers. It must be intelligent.
An intelligent kleptomaniac monster running through the halls at night. And here I thought school would be boring.
Maybe we can talk about this subject later. Ta-ta for now.
Hopefully, someone will catch the thief and we won't have to speculate on who or what the thief is. Take care.
How are you at rope climbing?
Worse than I was at throwing daggers, as it turns out.
So why aren't you over with Katie and Esme?
I thought I'd let them struggle with it first.

options.text: Say Something Clever to Reassure Thomas

nodes.text: The way class is going, we'll all be grappling with bigger problems than grapples, ropes, and Kwirks.
You saved the class by catching the Kwirk. We should all thank you for that. You've proved to everyone that you deserve to be here at Hero University.
It was just a Kwirk of fate that I'm here today.
You're the hero of the school. You caught the thief! You'll be promoted to Paladin school any day now.
I'm no hero. I was never in any danger. I just convinced the thief that it was wrong to steal, that's all.
You should go over to the ropes and tweak Katie about her rope climbing. After all, she went out of her way to tease you about dagger throwing.
No thanks. I felt badly whenever she mentioned my failure. I don't need to make her feel badly.

options.text: Say Something Polite to Compliment Thomas

nodes.text: Looks like all your practice is paying off. You're closer to the bullseye every day.
There is a book in the library, 'Zen and the Art of the Throw.' It really helped me improve my throwing skills.
Nice work catching the thief.
Thanks. It really wasn't that difficult. I'm surprised that someone else didn't do it before I did.
How did you catch him?
A few nights ago, I followed him to the Hall of Heroes and watched him go through the secret door there. So the next night, I put Gooey on his path.
So you caught the tricky thief in a sticky situation - Goo-ed job. I'd have done it myself if I had a glue.
So where did you come from, originally? You're clearly not from around Sardonia.
I grew up in Albion, but a few years ago, my father was sent here to protect the island. My mother and I eventually joined him here.
Then my father was killed.
That's why I got the scholarship to come here, because my father was a hero.
My father died when I was little. I barely remember him. So you're lucky to have your memories of your father.
I'll see you around, Thomas.
Goodbye.
